newsitem.title: FRANCE: France's BIC buys U.S. pen maker Sheaffer.
newsitem.headline: France's BIC buys U.S. pen maker Sheaffer.

text.p: France's BIC company, known for its trademark ball-points and disposable razors, said Thursday it acquired U.S. pen manufacturer Sheaffer.
"Sheaffer is a world-renowned brand, synonymous with high quality writing instruments," BIC chairman Bruno Bich said in a statement.
BIC said it was paying cash for the purchase from Gefinor S.A., a Luxemburg investment banking company based in Geneva Switzerland, that is the majority shareholder. Other terms were not disclosed.

The purchase of Sheaffer, which has annual sales of more than $50 million, is the latest in a series of BIC acquisitions aimed at expanding its product line. Last October it bought Germany's A. Hauser, which makes felt-tip pens.
BIC, which also manufactures lighters, bought the German holding company of the producer of Tipp-Ex liquid eraser in January. It also owns the Wite-out brand in North America.
It said its U.S.-based BIC Corp. subsidiary would acquire Sheaffer in a deal expected to close in mid-September, pending approval from U.S. antitrust authorities.

BIC's stock, which recently joined the CAC-40 blue chip index, rose 3.11 percent to 531 francs on the deal. A stockbroker said the acquisition increases BIC's dollar exposure. "But it's nothing to write home about," he quipped.

Sheaffer, based in Fort Madison, Iowa, sells inexpensive fountain pens available in drugstores, as well as the more exclusive 'White Dot' pens that cost up to $5,000. BIC said the global luxury pen market was worth around $2.8 billion.
The U.S. company was founded in 1913 by Walter Sheaffer, who invented the first refillable fountain pen five years earlier.
Sheaffer employs 550 people, 450 of them in North America. It owns 75 percent of the Shanghai Wingsung Stationery Co. Ltd venture.
